{{refimprove|date=August 2016}} {{Year box}} '''1802 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 20 August — [[James Belcher|Jem Belcher]] successfully defends his English title by defeating Joe Berks in 13 rounds at "Hanover Spa" in London.<ref name="JB">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/belcher-jem.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Jem Belcher]. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref>

{{Infobox Americas Cup competition |competition= 0th America's Cup |image= |image size= |image alt= |caption=
|defender country= United Kingdom |defender flag variant= |defender burgee= Royal-Yacht-Squadron-Burgee.svg |defender club= [[Royal Yacht Squadron]]<ref name=Britannica/> |defender yacht= 8 cutters, 9 schooners
|challenger country= United States |challenger flag variant= |challenger burgee= Burgee of the New York Yacht Club.svg |challenger club= [[New York Yacht Club]]<ref name=CBSNews-ThenAndNow-1851/> |challenger yacht= [[America (yacht)|America]]<ref name=Britannica/>
|location= [[Isle of Wight]], UK <ref name=Britannica/> |coordinates= |dates= 22 August 1851<ref name=Britannica/> |rule= |winning club= New York Yacht Club<ref name=CBSNews-ThenAndNow-1851/> |score= 1:0 }} {{commonscat}} The '''100 Guineas Cup'''<ref name=BoatDusseldorfISAF2003history> {{cite web |url= http://www.boat-duesseldorf.com/cipp/md_boot/custom/pub/content,oid,4306/lang,2/ticket,g_u_e_s_t/print,1 |title= History of The Auld Mug – Introducing the America's Cup |publisher= Boat Dusseldorf |author= ISAF |date= 2002 }} </ref> or '''Hundred Guinea Cup'''<ref name=Britannica> {{cite web |url= https://www.britannica.com/topic/Americas-Cup |title= America’s Cup (Hundred Guinea Cup) |publisher= Britannica |date= 28 June 2016 }} </ref> ('''£100 Cup''')<ref> {{cite web |url= http://america-scoop.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=75:pictures-of-the-race-1851&catid=53&Itemid=224&lang=en |title= Pictures of the £100 CUP (1851) |author= Yves Gary |date= 18 October 2015 |publisher= America's Scoop: America's Cup 1851–1937 }} </ref> [[regatta]] of 1851 was the first competition for the [[America's Cup]] trophy.<ref name=Britannica/> Originally, '''Cup of One Hundred Sovereigns''', the value of the trophy was 100 pounds-sterling, hence its names, variations on '''100 Pound Cup'''.<ref group=NB> Guinea, Sovereign, Quid, Pound, Pound-Sterling, £; are frequently used interchangeably, though there are slight differences in value </ref><ref name=RYS-America> {{cite web |url= https://www.rys.org.uk/about/the-yacht-america/ |title= The Yacht America |publisher= Royal Yacht Squadron |date= 2001 }} </ref><ref name=CBSNews-ThenAndNow-1851> {{cite news |url= http://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/americas-cup-yachts-then-and-now/ |title= America's Cup yachts: Then and now |page= 1/16 (1851) |publisher= CBS News }} </ref> The race was won by the yacht [[America (yacht)|''America'']], leading to the trophy being renamed "America's Cup".<ref name=Britannica/> The 1851 competition was the first to compete for the trophy now called the ''America's Cup'', hence the '''1851 America's Cup''' or '''0th America's Cup''' being zeroth, sequentially preceding the [[1870 America's Cup|first America's Cup of 1870]]. The event "The America's Cup" would not be founded until 1857, when the [[Deed of Gift of the America's Cup|deed of gift]] established the America's Cup racing regattas.<ref name=Britannica/> The 1851 edition was a [[fleet race]], unlike modern America's Cups finals, which are currently [[match race]]s.
==History== The race originated with an invitation for [[The Great Exhibition|the Great Exhibition of 1851]] by the [[Earl of Winton]], then Commodore of the [[Royal Yacht Squadron]] (RYS), inviting the recently formed [[New York Yacht Club]] (NYYC) to enjoy the facilities of the clubhouse of the RYS. John Cox Stevens, Commodore of the NYYC responded positively, and anticipated racing. Due to the RYS rules of the time, other races in the 1851 RYS Regatta were restricted to RYS members and their self-owned yachts, so the '''R. Y. S. £100 Cup''' was established, open to anyone to enter. At a RYS meeting on 9 May 1851, the race was scheduled for 22 August 1851. This race was to be the first of a series of challenge races for successive £100 Cups. At the time, it was normal practise for the winners to own the cups that were won, and not to return them for the next race to be won by others.<ref name=RYS-America/><ref name=AC-LRbar-RYSracing> {{cite web |url= http://land-rover-bar.americascup.com/en/royal.html |title= Royal Yacht Squadron Racing |work= Land Rover Bar |publisher= America's Cup }} </ref>
==Trophy== {{main|RYS £100 Cup}} The trophy, worth 100 [[Sovereign (British coin)|sovereign]]s in 1851, latterly affectionately known as the '''Auld Mug''', distinguishing it from the racing regatta of the same name.<ref name=BoatDusseldorfISAF2003history/>
The trophy, a bottomless [[ewer]], is made out of {{convert|134|oz|kg|abbr=on}} of [[silver]], and is {{convert|27|in|cm|abbr=on}} tall. The ewer was a stock item obtained from jeweler Robert Garrard in 1848.<ref name=RYS-America/><ref name=AC-LRbar-RYSracing/>
After the race it was engraved with the names of the yachts that raced against America, save the runner-up, ''Aurora''.<ref name=RYS-America/>
==Race== The regatta, held on 22 August 1851,<ref name=Britannica/> raced clockwise around the [[Isle of Wight]] in a [[fleet race]].<ref name=BoatDusseldorfISAF2003history/> The course was called "The Queen's Course".<ref name=RYS-America/> The course was near [[Cowes Castle]] on the Isle of Wight, where the [[Royal Yacht Squadron]] headquarters are located.<ref name=AC-LRbar-RYSracing/> The race took place as part of the ''1851 Royal Yacht Squadron Regatta''.<ref name=RYS1851RegattaPromo> {{cite |title= Royal Yacht Squadron Regatta, 1851 |publisher= Royal Yacht Squadron |date= 1851 |type= poster }} </ref> The signal gun for sailing was fired at 10am, and the winner saluted by a gun from the flag-ship at 8:34pm (8:37pm [[railway time]]).
18 yachts were entered for the race, but only 15 yachts started the race. The yacht ''Fernande'' did not make the start, while ''Strella'' and ''Titania'' both got to the starting line, though did not start the race. Those yachts that raced were ''America'', ''Alarm'', ''Arrow'', ''Aurora'', ''Bacchante'', ''Beatrice'', ''Brilliant'', ''Constance'', ''Eclipse'', ''Freak'', ''Gipsy Queen'', ''Ione'', ''Mona'', ''Volante'', and ''Wyvern''.<ref name=RYS-America/>

Carew || Camper || || || |- |style="text-align:center; background:grey; color:white;"| DSQ/DNF || Constance || Schooner || 218 || [[Marquis of Conyngham]] || Joseph White / East Cowes || || || |- |style="text-align:center; background:grey; color:white;"| DSQ/DNF || Freak || Cutter || 60 || William Curling || Wanhill || || || |- |style="text-align:center; background:grey; color:white;"| DSQ/DNF || Gipsy Queen || Schooner || 160 || Henry Bold Hoghton || White || || || |- |style="text-align:center; background:grey; color:white;"| DSQ/DNF || Ione || Schooner || 75 || Almon Hill || White || || || |- |style="text-align:center; background:grey; color:white;"| DSQ/DNF || Mona || Cutter || 82 || Alfred Paget || Richard Pinney / Poole || || || |- |style="text-align:center; background:grey; color:white;"| DSQ/DNF || Volante || Cutter || 48 || J.L. Craigie || Harvey / Ipswich || [[Royal Thames Yacht Club]] & [[Royal London Yacht Club]] || || |- |style="text-align:center; background:grey; color:white;"| DSQ/DNF || Wyvern || Schooner || 205 || [[George Spencer-Churchill, 6th Duke of Marlborough|Duke of Marlborough]] || Camper || || || |- |style="text-align:center; background:black; color:white;" | DSQ/DNS || Fernande || Schooner || 127 || Francis Mountjoy Martyn || William Camper / Gosport || || || |- |style="text-align:center; background:black; color:white;" | DNS || Strella || Cutter || 65 || Richard Frankland || George & James Inman / Lymington || || || |- |style="text-align:center; background:black; color:white;" | DNS || Titania || Schooner || 100 || R. Stephenson || Robinson and Russell / Millwall || || || |} <small> * DSQ/DNF – competitor did not finish under the time limit * DSQ/DNS – competitor did not make it to the starting line * DNS – did not start – competitor did not make it off the starting line * DNF – did not finish * DSQ – disqualified </small> <ref name=RYS-America/>
==Aftermath== {{main|America's Cup}} The trophy would be renamed "[[America's Cup]]" after the [[America (yacht)|yacht ''America'']], that won the trophy. In 1857, the competition for "America's Cup" was declared, with the creation of the [[Deed of Gift of the America's Cup|deed of gift]]. The [[1870 America's Cup|first challenge]] would take place in 1870 under the deed of gift. This would initiate the oldest championship in sport.<ref name=Britannica/>
==Gallery== <gallery> File:33rd America's Cup Valencia.jpg|The trophy File:1851 Royal Yacht Squadron Regatta promo.jpg|A flyer from the RYS for, among other things, the race. In it, the race is referred to as the "R.Y.S. £100 Cup". File:The Yacht 'America' Winning the International Race Fitz Hugh Lane 1851.jpeg|''America'', the winner, crossing the finish line File:The 193 ton yacht Alarm in a light swell.jpg|''Alarm'', largest yacht in the regatta </gallery>
==Footnotes== {{reflist|group=NB}}

{{unreferenced|date=August 2009}} The '''1995 Caribbean Series''' (''Serie del Caribe'') was the twenty-fifth edition of the second stage of the [[Caribbean Series]]. It was held in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]] from February 3 to February 9. The series featured four teams from [[Dominican Republic]], [[Mexico]], [[Puerto Rico]] and [[Venezuela]]. The hometown team, the [[Senadores de San Juan]] of the [[Professional Baseball League of Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican League]] won the series. The team was managed by [[Luis Meléndez (baseball)|Luis Meléndez]]. The [[Caribbean Series Most Valuable Player|Most Valuable Player]] was [[Roberto Alomar]], a second baseman with the [[Senadores de San Juan]].
While the San Juan club had faced difficulty in emerging as the champions of the [[Professional Baseball League of Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican Winter League]], the team swept its way through the six-game Series by a 49-15 score. The [[Azucareros del Este]] of the [[Dominican Winter Baseball League|Dominican League]] lost one game 16-0 by Puerto Rico. However they won all of their games against the other teams thanks to the arms of [[José Rijo]], [[Pedro Martínez]] and [[Pedro Astacio]] to place second with a 4-2 record.
Puerto Rico was helped by having many major leaguers who normally would have taken off the time for [[spring training]]. [[Roberto Alomar]] (.560, 10 RBI, 9 R, .840 SLG, 2 SB) was the Series MVP and he was helped by [[Bernie Williams]] (.417, .875 SLG), [[Juan González (baseball)|Juan González]] (.375, .667 SLG), [[Edgar Martínez]] (.375, 9 RBI), [[Carlos Baerga]], [[Rubén Sierra]], a young [[Carlos Delgado]] hitting cleanup, [[Roberto Hernández (relief pitcher)|Roberto Hernández]], [[Rey Sánchez]] (.333), [[Doug Brocail]] (1-0, 1.00), [[José Alberro]] (1-0, 0.00 in 4 games), [[Eric Gunderson]] (1-0, 1.13), [[Ricky Bones]] and [[Chris Haney]] (2.45) among others. Sanchez had won the Puerto Rican Winter League batting title but batted 9th with the superb lineup in front of him.

revision.text:
{{for|the fly genus|Actia (genus)}} [[Image:Remains of the stadium at Nikopolis.JPG|thumb|right|300px|The stadium of Nikopolis at present]] In [[Ancient Roman religion|Ancient Roman religious tradition]], '''Actia''' ([[Greek language|Greek]]: ''{{lang|grc|Ἄκτια}})'' was a festival of [[Apollo]], celebrated at [[Nicopolis]] in [[Epirus]], with [[wrestling]], musical contests, [[horse racing]], and sea battles. It was reestablished by [[Augustus]], in commemoration of his [[Battle of Actium|victory]] over [[Mark Antony]] off [[Actium]] in 31 BC; that it was probably the revival of an ancient festival is suggested by the celebrated temple of Apollo at Actium, which is mentioned by [[Thucydides]],<ref>''[[History of the Peloponnesian War]]'', i.29</ref> and [[Strabo]],<ref>''[[Geographica (Strabo)|The Geography]]'', vii p325</ref> and which was enlarged by Augustus. The games instituted by Augustus were celebrated every four years (''{{lang|grc|πενταετηρίς}}'', ''[[ludi]] quinquennales''); they received the title of a sacred ''[[agon]]'' and were also called [[Ancient Olympics in various places|Olympia]].<ref>Strabo, ''The Geography'' l.c.; [[Dio Cassius]], ''Roman History'', li.1; [[Suetonius]], ''[[Lives of the Twelve Caesars]]'', "Life of Augustus", 18; [[Philipp August Böckh|Böckh]], ''Corpus Inscriptionum Graecarum'', No. 1720, p845; J.H. Krause, ''Olympia'', p221.</ref>
==Stadium of Nikopolis==
This ancient stadium was located in the so-called 'Proasteion' ([[sacred grove]]) of the Graeco-Roman city of Nikopolis. Together with the nearby gymnasion, theatre and hippodrome it was the location of the famous Actian Games. These games, which featured athletic, equestrian and musical events, were first held in 27 BCE to celebrate the victory of the first Roman emperor Augustus over his adversaries, Marc Antony and his Egyptian wife [[Cleopatra]]. They were held every four years up to the mid-3rd century CE.
Dating from just after the city's foundation, the ancient stadium of Nikopolis has two semicircular ends (''sphendones''), typical of the amphitheatre type that was in use during the first 200 years of the principate. The stadiums of ancient Laodikeia (near Pamukkale, Turkey) and Aphrodisias (Geyre, Turkey) have a similar architecture.
The north side of the stadium, which must have held a capacity of at least 10,000 spectators, was built on the side of a hill, while artificial deposits were used for the other sides. The walls were made of a rubble core faced with several courses of bricks. On the west side of the stadium were three apsidal entrances leading to the gymnasion, the central one larger than the others. The entrances in the ''sphendone'' at the east led to the theatre nearby. On the ''sphendone'' at the south side there were residential rooms and facilities for athletes and spectators (inns, shops, lodgings etc.)
Locals call this stadium ''to karavi'', meaning 'the ship', which of course relates to the structure's shape. Archaeological investigations are still regularly undertaken in and around the stadium today. [[Image:Nikopolis1.jpg|thumb|Archaeological research at the stadium in November 2006]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox Organisation |name = Assam Football Association |abbreviation = AFA |headquarters = R.G. Baruah Sports Complex, Nehru Stadium, Guwahati |region_served = [[Assam]], [[India]] |leader_title = President |leader_name = Hemendra Nath Brahma {{cite web | url=https://www.the-aiff.com/state-associations-details.htm?id=34 | title=State Associations | publisher=All India Football Federation | accessdate=5 October 2018 }} |parent_organisation = [[All India Football Federation]] }} The '''Assam Football Association''' ('''AFA''') is one of the 36 [[Indian State Football Associations]] that are affiliated to the [[All India Football Federation]] and its current president is Hemendra Nath Brahma, while secretary is Ankur Dutta.https://khelnow.com/governingbody/Assam_Football_Association Assam Football Association was formed in 1951, but the game of [[Association football|football]] has been played since before independence of India. The game of Football was introduced by and an institution and some individual persons. It is affiliated to the [[All India Football Federation]], Assam council of sports and Assam Olympic association. The association controls men and women football game in the state of Assam. The game of football is very much popular in the four district viz. [[Dibrugarh]], [[Kokrajhar]], [[Karbi Anglong]] and [[Dima Hasao]]. The team of Association member is four years. The Nature of election of office bearers is based on the affiliated district units of football to Assam Football Association. AFA's premier top division league is [[Assam State Premier League]]. ==Assam Football Pyramid== The Assam Football Structure is based in two state level leagues followed by the district leagues which can go on for many levels. Apart from these leagues the Guwahati Sports Association also has a different structure of leagues for the Guwahati based clubs. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !colspan="1" width="20%" | Level !colspan="6" width="80%" | League(s)/Division(s) |- |colspan="1" width="20%" | '''1''' |colspan="8" width="80%" | '''[[Assam State Premier League]]'''

revision.text:
{{cleanup|date=October 2018|reason=list of winners in reverse chronological order, contrary to [[WP:DATELIST]]}} {{Infobox horseraces | class = | horse race = Futurity Stakes | image = | caption = | location = [[Belmont Park]]
[[Elmont, New York]], [[United States]] | inaugurated = 1888 | race type = [[Thoroughbred]] – [[Flat racing]] | website = {{URL|https://www.nyra.com/belmont/}} | distance = 6 furlongs | surface = Turf | track = Left-handed | qualification = Two-year-olds | weight = Assigned | purse = $150,000 | bonuses = }} The '''Futurity Stakes''', commonly referred to as the '''Belmont Futurity''', is an American [[Thoroughbred horse racing|Thoroughbred horse race]] run annually in mid-September or October at [[Belmont Park]] in [[Elmont, New York]], [[United States]]. Open to two-year-old horses, it is raced on turf over a distance of six [[furlong|furlongs]]. The creation of James G. K. Lawrence, president of the [[Sheepshead Bay Race Track]], the Futurity was originally run with the two-year-old offspring of [[mare|mares]] which had been nominated before their birth. This rule remained in effect until 1957, when the race was opened to all two-year-old horses. The Futurity was run as a [[grass|turf]] race for the first time in 2018. It was added to the [[Breeders' Cup Challenge]] series for 2018 as a "Win and You're In" qualifier for the [[Breeders' Cup Juvenile Turf Sprint|Juvenile Turf Sprint]].{{cite web |title=Breeders’ Cup Adds Three Juvenile Turf Sprint Qualifiers |url=http://www.thoroughbreddailynews.com/breeders-cup-adds-three-juvenile-turf-sprint-qualifiers/ |website=Thoroughbred Daily News |date=25 June 2018}} ==Inaugural running== The first edition of the Futurity took place on [[Labor Day]] in 1888. ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that one quarter of those in attendance were women. The richest race ever run in the United States to that time, the owners of winner [[Proctor Knott (horse)|Proctor Knott]] collected $41,675. Until 1956, this race had a larger purse than that of the [[Belmont Stakes]]. ===Food consumption=== ''The New York Times'' reported that attendance for the day of the inaugural running was at least the equal of the largest crowd to ever attend a race at the Sheepshead Bay facility and that the caterer sold the following food: {{div col|colwidth=25em}} * 12,000 pounds of [[lobster]] * 600 soft shell [[crab]]s * 500 gallons of [[clam chowder]] * 960 [[chicken]]s * 18,000 [[sandwich]]es * 50 sets of [[Ribs (food)|ribs]] * 60 [[short loin]]s * 20 [beef] hips and [[Loin#Loins in butchery|loins]] * 25 [[Lamb and mutton|Spring lamb]]s * 480 [[Domestic pigeon|squabs]] * 5 barrels of [[whiskey]] * 40 cases of pepper whiskey * 250 kegs of [[lager]] * 380 cases of [[Champagne (wine)|champagne]] * 30 barrels of imported [[ginger ale]] * 600 boxes of [[Club soda|soda water]], [[Sarsaparilla (soft drink)|sarsaparilla]], and other soft drinks {{div col end}} The Futurity Stakes was hosted by the Sheepshead Bay Race Track until the track's closure following a statewide ban on [[parimutuel betting]] through enactment of the [[Hart–Agnew Law]] by the [[New York State Legislature|New York Legislature]]. It was switched to the [[Saratoga Race Course]] for 1910 but was not raced for the next two years until the State Legislature lifted the ban. Held at Saratoga in 1913 and 1914, it was them moved to [[Belmont Park]]. In 1959 and 1960, plus from 1962 to 1967, the race was hosted by the [[Aqueduct Racetrack]] before returning to Belmont Park where it has since remained. The race's counterpart on [[grass|turf]] is the [[Laurel Futurity]] at [[Laurel Park Racecourse]] in [[Laurel, Maryland]]. Prior to the advent of the [[Breeders' Cup Juvenile]], the Belmont Futurity was one of the United States' most important dirt races for two-year-olds. Some of the greatest Thoroughbreds in American racing history have won the race including [[Colin (horse)|Colin]], [[Native Dancer]], [[Man o' War]] and [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing#United States Triple Crowns|U.S. Triple Crown]] champions, [[Affirmed]], [[Secretariat (horse)|Secretariat]], and [[Citation (horse)|Citation]]. In 2001, the race had been scheduled to be run on September 16 but was canceled following the [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001 attacks]]. Over the years the race has been contested at various distances: * 6 furlongs: 1888–1891, 1902–1924, 2011–present; * 1,263 yards and 1 foot: 1892–1901; * Approximately 7 furlongs: 1925–1933; * 6.5 furlongs: 1934–1975; * 7 furlongs: 1976–1993; 2005–2009. * 8 furlongs: 1994–2004. ==Records== '''Time record:''' * 7 Furlongs, Dirt: 1:21.60 – [[Affirmed]] (1977) * 6 1/2 Furlongs, Dirt: 1:14.40 – [[Native Dancer]] (1952) (World-Record Time) * 6 Furlongs, Dirt: 1:09.49 – Blofeld (2014) * 6 Furlongs, Turf: 1:11.26 - Uncle Benny (2018) '''Most wins by an owner:''' * 5 – [[James R. Keene]] (1893, 1899, 1907, 1908, 1909) * 5 – [[George D. Widener Jr.]] (1923, 1930, 1950, 1957, 1966) '''Most wins by a [[jockey]]:''' * 6 – [[Eddie Arcaro]] (1940, 1946, 1950, 1954, 1956, 1959) '''Most wins by a [[Horse trainer|trainer]]:''' * 9 – [[James G. {{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{short description|Irish stick-and-ball team sport played by women }} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox sport | image=Camogie.jpg | imagesize=300px | caption=A junior camogie match being played in [[Croke Park]], Dublin | union=[[Camogie Association]] | nickname= | first=Ireland | first team= 1904 | registered=Over 100,000 | clubs=536 | contact=[[Contact sports|Contact]] | team=15 players per side,
substitutes are permitted | mgender=[[Hurling]] is the male variant | ball=[[Sliotar]] (ball)
Hurley/camán (stick) Helmet Shin guards }} '''Camogie''' ({{IPAc-en|k|ɑː|m|ɔː|g|iː}}; {{lang-ga|camógaíocht}}) is an Irish stick-and-ball team sport played by women; it is almost identical to the game of [[hurling]] played by men. Camogie is played by 100,000 women in Ireland and worldwide, largely among Irish communities.{{cite book | last = Moran | first = Mary | authorlink = Mary Moran (camogie) | title = A Game of Our Own: The History of Camogie | publisher = Cumann Camógaíochta | year = 2011 | location = Dublin, Ireland | pages = 460}}{{cite book | last = Arlott | first = John | title = Oxford Companion to Sports and Games | publisher = Flamingo | year = 1977 | location = London, England | pages = 1024 }} It is organised by the Dublin-based [[Camogie Association]] or [[Camogie Association|An Cumann Camógaíochta]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.camogie.ie/about-camogie.asp|title=The Camogie Association : About Camogie|last=Vuepoint.ie|website=Camogie.ie|language=en|access-date=2017-05-05}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.gaa.ie/my-gaa/getting-involved/camogie|title=GAA.ie|website=Gaa.ie|language=en|access-date=2017-05-05}} [[UNESCO]] lists Camogie as an element of [[Intangible cultural heritage|Intangible Cultural Heritage]].{{Cite web|url=https://ich.unesco.org/en/RL/hurling-01263|title=Hurling - intangible heritage - Culture Sector - UNESCO|website=ich.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-29}} ==The game== The game consists of 2 thirty-minute halves. There is a half time interval of 10 minutes. In event of extra time halves must consist of 10 minutes each. Each team has 15 players on the field. Within the 15 players the team must consist of 1 goal keeper, 3 full back players, 3 half back players, 2 centre-field players, 3 half forward players and 3 full forward players. There is a minimum requirement of 12 players on the pitch at all times.{{cite web |url=http://www.camogie.ie/files/Administration+Section/Playing+Rules+2014.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-01-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116004430/http://www.camogie.ie/files/Administration+Section/Playing+Rules+2014.pdf |archivedate=16 January 2018 |df=dmy-all }} ===Field=== The field is not of a fixed size, but must be between 130m long by 80m wide, and 145m long by 90m wide. ===Goals and scoring=== {{Main|Scoring in Gaelic games}} H-shaped goals are used. A team achieves a score by making the ball go between the posts. If the ball goes over the bar for a "point", the team earns 1-point. If the ball goes under the bar for a "goal", the team earns a 3-points.{{cite web|url=http://www.camogie.ie/AboutCamogie/CamogiePlayingRules/tabid/59/Default.aspx|title=Rules of Camogie on Camogie.ie website|publisher=|accessdate=15 January 2018}} ==Profile of camogie== The annual [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship|All Ireland Camogie Championship]] has a record attendance of 33,1542007 All Ireland final reports in [http://www.examiner.ie/archives/2007/0910/sport/gaa-chiefs-vow-to-review-ticketing-system-following-glitch-42143.html Irish Examiner], [https://archive.is/20120802093242/http://www.independent.ie/other/wexfords-day-of-glory-1074735.html Irish Independent], [http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2007/0910/1189076008095.html Irish Times] and [http://www.goreyguardian.ie/sport/other-sports/leacy-goals-fire-wexford-to-emotional-victory-1079990.html Gorey Guardian] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219153020/http://www.goreyguardian.ie/sport/other-sports/leacy-goals-fire-wexford-to-emotional-victory-1079990.html |date=19 February 2012 }} while average attendances in recent years are in the region of 15,000 to 18,000. The final is televised live, with a TV audience of over 300,000 being claimed.{{cite book | last = [[Eoghan Corry|Corry]] | first = Eoghan | title = Illustrated History of the GAA | publisher = Gill & MacMillan | year = 2005 | location = Dublin, Ireland | pages = 250 }} ==Rules== The rules are almost identical to [[hurling]], with a few exceptions.{{cite web|url=http://www.camogie.ie/AboutCamogie/CamogievHurlingRuleDifferences/tabid/60/Default.aspx|title=Rule Differences on Camogie.ie website|publisher=|accessdate=15 January 2018}} *Goalkeepers wear the same colours as outfield players. This is because no special rules apply to the goalkeeper and so there is no need for officials to differentiate between goalkeeper and outfielders. *A camogie player can handpass any score from play ''(handpassing a goal is forbidden in hurling since 1980)'' *Camogie games last 60 minutes, two 30-minute halves ''(senior inter-county hurling games last 70, which is two 35-minute halves)''. Ties are resolved by multiple 2×10-minute [[Sudden death (sport)|sudden death]] extra time periods; in these, the first team to score wins. *Dropping the [[camogie stick]] to handpass the ball is permitted. *A smaller sliotar (ball) is used in camogie – commonly known as a size 4 sliotar – whereas hurlers play with a size 5 sliotar. *If a defending player hits the sliotar wide, a 45-metre puck is awarded to the opposition ''(in hurling, it is a 65-metre puck)'' *After a score, the goalkeeper pucks out from the 13-metre line. ''(in hurling, he must puck from the end line)'' *The metal band on the camogie stick must be covered with tape. ''(not necessary in hurling)'' *Side-to-side charges are forbidden. ''(permitted in hurling)'' *Two points are awarded for a score direct from a sideline cut (since March 2012).{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/hurling/ladies-sticking-with-skirts-as-oflynn-backs-rules-makeover-3066426.html|title=Ladies sticking with skirts as O'Flynn backs rules makeover - Independent.ie|publisher=|accessdate=15 January 2018}} Camogie players must wear [[skirt]]s or [[skort]]s rather than [[shorts]]. ==Foundation== Experimental rules were drawn up in 1903 for a female stick-and-ball game by [[Máire Ní Chinnéide]], [[Seán (Sceilg) Ó Ceallaigh]], [[Tadhg Ó Donnchadha]] and [[Séamus Ó Braonáin]]. The Official Launch of Camogie took place with the first public match between Craobh an Chéitinnigh (Keatings branch of the [[Gaelic League]]) and [[Cúchulainns]] on 17 July at a Feis in Navan. The sport's governing body, the Camogie Association or [[Camogie Association of Ireland|An Cumann Camógaíochta]] was founded in 1905 and re-constituted in 1911, 1923 and 1939. Until June 2010 it was known as Cumann Camógaíochta na nGael. Máire Ní Chinnéide and Cáit Ní Dhonnchadha, two prominent Irish-language enthusiasts and cultural nationalists, were credited with having created the sport, with the assistance of Ní Dhonnchadha's scholarly brother Tadhg Ó Donnchadha, who drew up its rules. Thus, although camogie was founded by women, and independently run (although closely linked to the GAA), there was, from the outset, a small yet powerful male presence within its administrative ranks. It was no surprise that camogie emanated from the Gaelic League, nor that it would be dependent upon the structures and networks provided by that organisation during the initial expansion of the sport. Of all the cultural nationalist organisations for adults that emerged during the fin de siècle, the Gaelic League was the only one to accept female and male members on an equal footing.Ríona Nic Congáil “'Looking on for centuries from the side-line': Gaelic Feminism and the rise of Camogie", Éire-Ireland (Spring / Summer 2013): 168–192.[https://www.academia.edu/3324668/Looking_on_for_centuries_from_the_side-line_Gaelic_Feminism_and_the_rise_of_Camogie Gaelic Feminism and the rise of Camogie] [[File:Camogie Team, Waterford, 17 October 1915.jpg|thumb|A camogie team pictured in Waterford in October 1915]] ==Historic rules== Under [[Séamus Ó Braonáin]]'s original 1903 camogie rules both the match and the field were shorter than their hurling equivalents. Matches were 40 minutes, increased to 50 minutes in 1934, and playing fields 125–130 yards (114-119m) long and 65–70 yards (59-64m) wide. From 1929 until 1979 a second crossbar, a "points bar" was also used, meaning that a point would not be allowed if it travelled over this bar, a somewhat contentious rule through the 75 years it was in use. Teams were regulated at 12 a side, using an elliptical formation (1–3–3–3–1) although it was more a "squeezed lemon" formation with the three midfield players grouped more closely together than their counterpart on the half back and half-forward lines. In 1999 camogie moved to the GAA field-size and 15-a-side, adopting the standard GAA butterfly formation (3–3–2–3–3). ==Nomenclature== The name was invented by [[Tadhg Ó Donnchadha|Tadhg Ua Donnchadha]] (Tórna) at meetings in 1903 in advance of the first matches in 1904. {{cite book | last = Puirséil | first = Pádraig | title = Scéal na Camógaíochta | publisher = [[Camogie Association of Ireland|Cumann Camógaíochta na nGael]] | year = 1984 | location = Dublin, Ireland | pages = 64 }} Men play using a curved stick called in Irish a ''camán''. Women would use a shorter stick, at one stage described by the diminutive form ''camóg''. The suffix -''aíocht'' (originally "uidheacht") was added to both words to give names for the sports: ''camánaíocht'' (which became ''iománaíocht'') and ''camógaíocht''. When the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] was founded in 1884 the English-origin name "hurling" was given to the men's game. When an organisation for women was set up in 1904, it was decided to anglicise the Irish name ''camógaíocht'' to ''camogie''. ==Structure== [[Camogie Association|An Cumann Camógaíochta]] has a similar structure to the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]], with an Annual Congress every spring which decides on policy and major issues such as rule changes, and an executive council, the Árd Chómhairle which deals with short-term issues and governance. The game is administered from a headquarters in [[Croke Park]] in Dublin. Each of 28 [[Gaelic Athletic Association county|county board]]s takes control of its own affairs (all of the Irish counties except [[Fermanagh GAA|Fermanagh]], [[Leitrim GAA|Leitrim]] and [[Sligo GAA|Sligo]]), with the number of clubs ranging from 58 in [[Cork GAA|Cork]] to one in [[Leitrim GAA|Leitrim]]. There are four provincial councils and affiliates in [[Asia GAA|Asia]], [[Australia GAA|Australia]], [[Britain GAA|Britain]], [[Europe GAA|Europe]], [[New York GAA|New York]], [[New Zealand GAA|New Zealand]] and [[North American GAA|North America]]. ==Camogie clubs== There are 537 camogie clubs, of which 513 (95.5%) are based on the island of Ireland, 47 in [[Connacht GAA#Camogie|Connacht]] (8.8%), 195 in [[Leinster GAA#Camogie|Leinster]] (36.4%), 160 in [[Munster GAA#Camogie|Munster]] (29.8%), and 110 in [[Ulster GAA#Camogie|Ulster]] (20.5%). {{Div col|colwidth=15em}} * [[Antrim GAA#Camogie|Antrim]] 22 * [[Armagh GAA#Camogie|Armagh]] 18 * [[Carlow GAA#Camogie|Carlow]] 6 * [[Cavan GAA#Camogie|Cavan]] 9 * [[Clare GAA#Camogie|Clare]] 26 * [[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]] 58 * [[Derry GAA#Camogie|Derry]] 23 * [[Donegal GAA#Camogie|Donegal]] 3 * [[Down GAA#Camogie|Down]] 21 * [[Dublin GAA#Camogie|Dublin]] 39 * [[Europe GAA#Camogie|Europe]] 4 * [[Fermanagh GAA#Camogie|Fermanagh]] 0 * [[Galway GAA#Camogie|Galway]] 34 * [[Kerry GAA#Camogie|Kerry]] 3 * [[Kildare GAA#Camogie|Kildare]] 19 * [[Kilkenny GAA#Camogie|Kilkenny]] 33 * [[Laois GAA#Camogie|Laois]] 7 * [[Leitrim GAA#Camogie|Leitrim]] 1 * [[Limerick GAA#Camogie|Limerick]] 25 * [[London GAA#Camogie|London]] 7 * [[Longford GAA#Camogie|Longford]] 1 * [[Louth GAA#Camogie|Louth]] 6 * [[Mayo GAA#Camogie|Mayo]] 3 * [[Meath GAA#Camogie|Meath]] 14 * [[Monaghan GAA#Camogie|Monaghan]] 4 * [[New South Wales GAA#Camogie|New South Wales]] 5 * [[North American GAA#Camogie|N America]] 7 * [[Offaly GAA#Camogie|Offaly]] 12 * [[Roscommon GAA#Camogie|Roscommon]] 7 * [[Sligo GAA#Camogie|Sligo]] 2 * [[Tipperary GAA#Camogie|Tipperary]] 32 * [[Tyrone GAA#Camogie|Tyrone]] 10 * [[Waterford GAA#Camogie|Waterford]] 16 * [[Australasia GAA#Camogie|W. Australia]] 1 * [[Westmeath GAA#Camogie|Westmeath]] 13 * [[Wexford GAA#Camogie|Wexford]] 33 * [[Wicklow GAA#Camogie|Wicklow]] 13 * [[Toronto GAA#Camogie|Toronto]] 2 {{Div col end}} ==Competitions== ===All-Ireland Championship=== The county is the unit of structure in elite competition, responsible for organising club competitions within the county unit and for fielding inter-county teams in the various grades of the [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship|All-Ireland championships]] and [[National Camogie League]]. * Eleven counties will compete for the elite [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship]] in 2018 for which the [[O'Duffy Cup]] is awarded: [[Clare GAA#Camogie|Clare]], [[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]], [[Dublin GAA#Camogie|Dublin]], [[Galway GAA#Camogie|Galway]], [[Kilkenny GAA#Camogie|Kilkenny]], [[Limerick GAA#Camogie|Limerick]], [[Meath GAA#Camogie|Meath]], [[Offaly GAA#Camogie|Offaly]], [[Tipperary GAA#Camogie|Tipperary]], [[Waterford GAA#Camogie|Waterford]], and [[Wexford GAA#Camogie|Wexford]]. The All-Ireland Final is held every year in [[Croke Park]] during September, usually on the week between the [[hurling]] final and [[Gaelic football]] final, and attracts attendances of up to 33,000. The [[2017 All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship|champions for 2017]] are Cork. * The [[All-Ireland Senior Club Camogie Championship|All Ireland Club Championship]] is staged at Senior, Intermediate and Junior level, usually reaching the final stages in November–December or the following March. * Eleven teams will contest the second-tier [[All-Ireland Intermediate Camogie Championship|Jack McGrath Cup]] in 2018 (All Ireland intermediate championship): [[Antrim GAA#Camogie|Antrim]], [[Carlow GAA#Camogie|Carlow]], [[Derry GAA#Camogie|Derry]], [[Down GAA#Camogie|Down]], [[Kildare GAA#Camogie|Kildare]], [[Laois GAA#Camogie|Laois]], and [[Westmeath GAA#Camogie|Westmeath]], and the second teams of [[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]], [[Galway GAA#Camogie|Galway]], [[Kilkenny GAA#Camogie|Kilkenny]], and [[Tipperary GAA#Camogie|Tipperary]]. * Seven teams contested the third-tier [[Kay Mills Cup]] (All Ireland junior or 'Premier Junior" championship) in 2018: [[Armagh GAA#Camogie|Armagh]], [[Kerry GAA#Camogie|Kerry]], [[Roscommon GAA#Camogie|Roscommon]], and the second teams of [[Clare GAA#Camogie|Clare]], [[Dublin GAA#Camogie|Dublin]], [[Limerick GAA#Camogie|Limerick]], and [[Offaly GAA#Camogie|Offaly]]. * Six teams contest the fourth-tier [[All-Ireland Junior Camogie Championship#Nancy Murray Cup|Nancy Murray Cup]] (or Junior A championship), [[Carlow GAA#Camogie|Carlow]], [[Cavan GAA#Camogie|Cavan]], [[Monaghan GAA#Camogie|Monaghan]], [[Tyrone GAA#Camogie|Tyrone]], [[Westmeath GAA#Camogie|Westmeath]], and the second team of [[Offaly GAA#Camogie|Offaly]]. * Three teams contest the fifth-tier [[All-Ireland Junior Camogie Championship#Máire Ní Chinnéide Cup|Máire Ní Chinnéide Cup]], (or Junior B championship), [[Wicklow GAA#Camogie|Wicklow]],and the second teams of [[Kildare GAA#Camogie|Kildare]] and [[Meath GAA#Camogie|Meath]]. * [[London GAA#Camogie|London]] competed in the ((National Camogie League)) in The [[National Camogie League 2010|2010]] season although not in [[National Camogie League 2011|2011]]. * Although six counties do not compete at adult level: [[Donegal GAA#Camogie|Donegal]], [[Fermanagh GAA#Camogie|Fermanagh]], [[Leitrim GAA#Camogie|Leitrim]], [[Longford GAA#Camogie|Longford]], [[Mayo GAA#Camogie|Mayo]] and [[Sligo GAA#Camogie|Sligo]] do not compete at adult level, clubs from [[Fermanagh GAA#Camogie|Fermanagh]], [[Kerry GAA#Camogie|Kerry]] and [[Mayo GAA#Camogie|Mayo]] have won honours and [[Donegal GAA#Camogie|Donegal]] have contested divisional finals at under-14 [[Feile na nGael]] level. Both [[Louth GAA#Camogie|Louth]] (in [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship 1934|1934]] and [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship 1936|1936]]) and [[Mayo GAA#Camogie|Mayo]] (in [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship 1959|1959]]) have contested the [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship|All Ireland senior final]] in the past. *There are age-graded All Ireland championships at [[All-Ireland Minor Camogie Championship|Minor A]], [[All-Ireland Minor Camogie Championship#All Ireland Minor B Finals|Minor B]], and [[All-Ireland Minor Camogie Championship#All Ireland Minor C Finals|Minor C]], and [[All-Ireland Minor Camogie Championship#All Ireland Under-16 Camogie Finals|Under-16 A]], [[All-Ireland Minor Camogie Championship#All Ireland Under-16 B Finals|B]] and [[All-Ireland Minor Camogie Championship#All Ireland Under-16 C Finals|C]] level. ===National League=== The [[National Camogie League|National League]] is staged during the winter-spring months, with four divisions of team graded by ability. ===Provincial championships=== Provincial championships take place at all levels, independent of the All Ireland series which has been run on an open draw basis since 1973. ===International and inter-provincial=== Ireland plays a [[Composite rules shinty-hurling|camogie-shinty]] international against [[Shinty|Scotland]] each year. The [[Gael Linn Cup]] is an inter-provincial competition played at senior and junior level. The sport is closely associated with the [[Celtic Congress]]. Two former [[Camogie Association]] presidents [[Máire Ní Chinnéide]] and [[Agnes O'Farrelly]] were also presidents of [[Celtic Congress]] and exhibition matches have been held at the Celtic Congress since 1938. The first such exhibition match, on the [[Isle of Man]] in 1938, marked the first appearance of [[Kathleen Cody (athlete)|Kathleen Cody]], who became one of the stars of the 1940s. ===Inter-collegiate=== The [[Ashbourne Cup|Ashbourne]] and Purcell Cups and Father Meachair seven-a-side are the principal inter-collegiate competitions. ===Schools=== There is also a programme of [[All Ireland Colleges Camogie Championship|provincial and All Ireland championships at secondary schools senior and junior levels]], differentiated by the years of secondary school cycle, with years 4–6 competing in the senior competition, and years 1–3 competing at junior level. [[Cumann na mBunscoil]] organises competitions at primary school level. ===Féile na nGael=== Camogie competitions for club teams featuring under-14 players are played in four divisions as part of the annual [[Féile na nGael]] festival. The county that is selected for a particular year, all their clubs host teams from all around the country representing their county. Host clubs get families to take in two or three children for a couple of days. ==Records== Cork have won the most Camogie All-Ireland titles a with 27 the last being in 2017. See [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship]]. [[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]] have won the most [[National Camogie League]] titles with 16. See [[National Camogie League]] Wexford having won three in a row from 2010 to 2012 ==Awards== [[Camogie All Stars Awards]] are awarded annually to the elite players who have performed best in each of the 15 positions on a traditional camogie team. Player of the year and other achievement awards have also been awarded to leading players for several decades. ===Team of the Century=== Picked in 2004{{cite web|url=http://www.camogie.ie/AboutCamogie/TeamoftheCentury/tabid/103/Default.aspx|title=Team of the century |website=Camogie.ie|accessdate=15 January 2018}} #[[Eileen Duffy|Eileen Duffy-O'Mahony]] ([[Dublin GAA#Camogie|Dublin]]) #[[Liz Neary]] ([[Kilkenny GAA#Camogie|Kilkenny]]) #[[Marie Costine|Marie Costine-O'Donovan]] ([[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]]) #[[Mary Sinnott|Mary Sinnott-Dinan]] ([[Wexford GAA#Camogie|Wexford]]) #[[Bridie McGarry|Bridie Martin-McGarry]] ([[Kilkenny GAA#Camogie|Kilkenny]]) #[[Sandie Fitzgibbon]] ([[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]]) #[[Margaret O'Leary|Margaret O'Leary-Leacy]] ([[Wexford GAA#Camogie|Wexford]]) #[[Mairéad McAtamney|Mairéad McAtamney-Magill]] ([[Antrim GAA#Camogie|Antrim]]) # [[Linda Mellerick]] ([[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]]) # [[Sophie Brack]] ([[Dublin GAA#Camogie|Dublin]]) #[[Kathleen Mills|Kathleen Mills-Hill]] ([[Dublin GAA#Camogie|Dublin]]) #[[Joni Traynor]] ([[London GAA#Camogie|Kilkenny]]) #[[Úna O'Connor]] ([[Dublin GAA#Camogie|Dublin]]) #[[Pat Moloney|Pat Moloney-Lenihan]] ([[Cork GAA#Camogie|Cork]]) #[[Deirdre Hughes]] ([[Tipperary GAA#Camogie|Tipperary]]) #[[Angela Downey|Angela Downey-Browne]] ([[Kilkenny GAA#Camogie|Kilkenny]]) ==Literary references== A reference to camogie features in one of Lucky's speeches in ''[[Waiting for Godot]]'' by Irish playwright [[Samuel Beckett]]. ==See also== {{Portal|Gaelic games}} * [[Women's shinty]] * [[Camogie All Stars Awards]] * [[Ashbourne Cup]] * [[Poc Fada]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Wiktionary|camogie}} * [http://www.camogie.ie Camogie.ie] Official Camogie Association Website {{Gaelic games}} {{Ladies' Gaelic games}} {{Gaelic Athletic Association}} {{Team sports}} {{Women's sports}} [[Category:Camogie| ]] [[Category:Gaelic games]] [[Category:Sports originating in Ireland]] [[Category:Team sports]]

{{Infobox stadium |stadium_name = Cessna Stadium |nickname = |image = CessnaStdm.jpg |image_size = 250px |location = 1845 E 21st Street N
[[Wichita, Kansas]] 67260 |broke_ground = January 6, 1941 |opened = September 21, 1946 |renovated = 1969, 1996, 2002 |closed = |demolished = |owner = [[Wichita State University]] |operator = [[Wichita State University]] |surface = grass |construction_cost = $100,000
$1,500,000 (1969)
$1,800,000 (2002 renovation) |architect = |former_names = Veterans Field (1946–1968) |tenants = [[Wichita State Shockers]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]])
[[Kapaun Mt. Carmel High School]] football |seating_capacity = 16,000 (1946–1968)
31,500 (1969–2002)
24,000 (2002–present) }} '''Cessna Stadium''' is a 24,000 seat stadium in [[Wichita, Kansas]], United States. It is located on the south side of 21st Street, east of Hillside, on the campus of [[Wichita State University]] in northeast Wichita. Cessna is currently the home of the [[Wichita State University#Shockers|Shocker]] [[track and field]] team. Before the WSU football program was discontinued, the Shocker [[Wichita State Shockers football|football]] team played home games at this stadium. ==History== In the early days of Wichita State University, when it was known as Fairmount College, its first football field was located on the north side of 17th Street, immediately east of the current Henrion Hall, when it was the Henrion Gymnasium. In 1929, concrete bleachers were attached to the east side of the same building for football games.[http://www.wichita.edu/thisis/buildingtour/?tour_sysid=32 Henrion Hall; Wichita State University.] In 1940, the school decided to build a new football stadium on the north side of campus at the current site on the south side of 21st Street. On January 6, 1941, ground was broken for '''Veterans Field''', and by September 1942 the bowl was excavated, foundations were poured for the west stands, and a quarter of the west bleachers were completed, however construction was halted due to metal shortages during [[World War II]]. After the war ended, the bleachers were constructed in sections over time as funds were incrementally available. By mid-1946, stands were completed to a point where 6,000 seats were ready by the start of the 1946 football season. Veterans Field was finally completed before the start of the 1948 football season, with 15,000 seats and facilities for the press, concessions stands, and locker rooms. It was dedicated on November 25, 1948 during a football game with the [[University of Nevada]]. The stadium was dedicated to the members of the armed forces from Sedgwick County who served in World War II.[http://specialcollections.wichita.edu/collections/local_history/tihen/pdf/People&Places/Veterans_Field.PDF Notes from Wichita newspapers about Veterans Field and Cessna Stadium; Dr. Edward N. Tihen; Wichita State University.][http://www.wichita.edu/thisis/stories/story.asp?si=1273 Wichita State to celebrate Veterans Field on Veterans Day; November 1, 2010; Wichita State University.] 1n 1967, Wichita State started considering the expansion of Veterans Field. In 1968, faculty and students voted and approved the expansion by adding on top of the existing stands of Veterans Field. [[Cessna Aircraft Company]] pledged a donation of $300,000 for the proposed stadium, and it was renamed to Cessna Stadium. The cost of the expansion was $1.5 Million, and the school had a fund drive to raise the remaining money. Construction was started on February 7, 1969 and completed in September. It was one of the most modern and complete football facilities in the nation at the time of its completion.[http://www.wichita.edu/thisis/buildingtour/?tour_sysid=14 Cessna Stadium; Wichita State University.] Wichita State University rededicated the facility on April 16, 2002 to mark the end of the seven-month, $1.3 million construction that included adding an eighth lane and resurfacing the track, reconfiguring the infield event layout, and building separate locker rooms for the Shocker men's and women's track and field teams. The first event in the renovated facility was WSU's annual K.T. Woodman Track and Field Classic, which is scheduled every April. ===Football=== {{See also|Wichita State Shockers football}} The Wichita State Shockers football team was a [[NCAA]] Division I football program. The Shockers fielded a team from 1897 to 1986.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mi4tAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Er0EAAAAIBAJ&dq=wichita%20state%20drops%20football&pg=4330%2C5638503|title=Wichita State drops football|agency=Associated Press|date=December 3, 1986|publisher=The Rock Hill Herald|pages=Page 10A|accessdate=8 July 2012|location=Wichita, Kansas}}{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5CRHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4zMNAAAAIBAJ&dq=wichita%20state%20drops%20football&pg=5758%2C198862|title=Wichita State suspends football program |date=December 3, 1986|publisher=The Evening News|pages=Page 2B|accessdate=8 July 2012}} They played home games at Cessna Stadium and were members of the [[Missouri Valley Conference football|Missouri Valley Conference]] when the program was discontinued in 1986. Cessna was the location of a [[Pittsburg State University|Pittsburg State]]-[[Colorado Mesa University|Mesa State]] [[NCAA Division II|Division II]] college football game. The stadium has also played host to numerous Kansas State High School Football Championship games, including the [[Kansas Shrine Bowl]], Kansas's high school all-star football game, [[High school (North America)|High School]] football games from nearby [[Kapaun Mt. Carmel High School]].{{cite web |url=http://webs.wichita.edu/gs/cessnastadium.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-07-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060905091905/http://webs.wichita.edu/gs/cessnastadium.html |archivedate=2006-09-05 |df= }} Cessna Stadium facts from W.S.U. Athletics Website ==Current use== ===Track and field=== [[Wichita State Shockers]] track and field currently uses the facilities, as well as several [[Missouri Valley Conference]] Track and Field Championship meets. In April of each year, Cessna Stadium is the venus for the K.T. Woodman Classic, a track and field meet for high schools, junior colleges, and many top collegiate track programs of the midwest.[http://sidearm.sites.s3.amazonaws.com/wichita.sidearmsports.com/documents/2016/4/13/Meet_History.pdf K.T. Woodman Classic History.][http://www.nmnathletics.com/fls/7500/MeetsHistory37.pdf K.T. Woodman Classic Meet History.] ===Football=== Cessna is used by [[Kapaun Mt. Carmel High School|Kapaun Mount Carmel High School]] of the Greater Wichita Athletic League as its "home field" for varsity football games.[http://www.kapaun.org/football/218-2016-football-schedule Kapaun 2016 Varsity Football Schedule; Kapaun Mt. Carmel High School.] Other high school games are played at Cessna Stadium from time to time. ===Public=== Cessna Stadium is open to the public for recreational use Monday through Friday from 6:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. It is closed on holidays and during WSU track & field practices and special events.[https://web.archive.org/web/20060905091905/http://webs.wichita.edu/gs/cessnastadium.html Cessna Stadium; WSU.][http://www.goshockers.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=7500&ATCLID=204983678 New Open Track Schedule for Cessna Stadium; WSU; August 27, 2010.] In April 2017, WSU decided to change their policy, a $100 deposit is now required to get a key to use their facilities.[http://www.kake.com/story/35154435/deposit-now-required-for-public-use-of-cessna-stadium Deposit now required for public use of Cessna Stadium; KAKE TV; April 14, 2017/] ==See also== ; Sports facilities on WSU campus * [[Charles Koch Arena]] (basketball and volleyball) * [[Eck Stadium]] (baseball) ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Cessna Stadium}} * [http://www.wichita.edu/thisis/buildingtour/?tour_sysid=14 Cessna Stadium information], wichita.edu * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120617024139/http://webs.wichita.edu/depttools/depttoolsmemberfiles/aboutwsu/WSU_MAP_NEW.pdf WSU Campus Map], wichita.edu ;Historical * [http://www.wichita.edu/thisis/wsunews/news/?nid=1273 Wichita State celebrates Veterans Field rededication in 2010], wichita.edu * Photos: :* [http://www.wichitaphotos.org/graphics/wsu_ua.wsu.campus_aerial.5.pdf 1965 aerial view of Veterans Field], wichitaphotos.org :* [http://sidearm.sites.s3.amazonaws.com/wichita.sidearmsports.com/documents/2015/11/12/Section5_History_66-83.pdf 1955 aerial view of west side of Veterans Field during construction of Round House], photo at bottom of page 68 :* [http://www.wichitaphotos.org/graphics/wsu_ua.wsu.campus_aerial.4.pdf 1955 aerial view of original football field along 17th street], wichitaphotos.org {{Wichita State University}} {{Wichita State Shockers football navbox}} {{Kansas college football venues}} {{Music venues of Kansas}} {{Wichita}} {{coord|37|43|18.12|N|97|17|43.87|W|region:US_type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Kansas]] [[Category:College track and field venues in the United States]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Kansas]] [[Category:Music venues in Kansas]] [[Category:Defunct college football venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Wichita, Kansas]] [[Category:American football venues in Kansas]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Wichita, Kansas]] [[Category:1969 establishments in Kansas]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1969]] [[Category:College soccer venues in the United States]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox swimming venue |name = Debrecen Swimming Pool Complex |logo = |logosize = |logocaption = |image = Debreceni sportuszoda.jpg |imagesize = |caption = |fullname = |nicknames = |city = [[Debrecen]], [[Hungary]] |coordinates = {{coord|47|32|47|N|21|38|17|E|type:landmark|display=title,inline }} |capacity = 2,000{{cite web|url=http://www.debrecen2012.com/musz/musz_uszoeb.eng.news.page?nodeid=1935|title=Venue|publisher=2012 European Aquatics Championships official website|accessdate=24 March 2012}} |built = October 2005 – September 2006 |opened = October 2006 |closed = |demolished = |architects = |construction cost= €12 million |home clubs = |poolname = |length = |width = |deep = |lanes = |tenants = {{nowrap|[[Debreceni Cívis Póló Vízilabda SE]]}} |footnotes = }} The '''Debrecen Swimming Pool Complex''' is an aquatics venue in [[Debrecen]], Hungary. The facility features a competitive long course pool, a warm up pool, a training pool, Jacuzzi, sauna and an outdoor thermal bath with a water temperature of 34–36 °C (93–97 °F). The 50 metres long course pool can be reduced to 33 metres or 25 metres by a mobile wall, making it available for short course events.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportuszoda.hu/bemutatkozas.html|title=Bemutatkozás|trans-title=Introduction|publisher=Debrecen Swimming Pool Complex official website|accessdate=24 March 2012|language=Hungarian}} The construction of the pool began in October 2005 and took 11 months to complete. It was opened in October 2006 with a three-day-long inauguration festival, that included water polo matches and swimming competitions. The opening ceremony featured [[Tamás Gyárfás]], president of the Hungarian Swimming Association and [[Lajos Kósa]], mayor of Debrecen, while the [[ribbon-cutting ceremony]] was carried out by five time Olympic champion [[Krisztina Egerszegi]].{{cite web|url=http://epulettar.hu/cikk/haromnapos-uszodaavatas|title=Háromnapos uszodaavatás|trans-title=Three day long pool inauguration|publisher=Épülettár|date=16 October 2006|accessdate=24 March 2012|language=Hungarian}} The first major event held in the venue was the [[2007 European Short Course Swimming Championships]], which was followed by a number of national and international swimming and water polo competitions. In February 2012, after [[Antwerp]] withdrew from organizing the swimming events [[2012 European Aquatics Championships]], Debrecen stepped in as the new host and the races are now set to take place at the pool complex between 21–27 May 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.swimnews.com/news/view/9208|title=Euros: Debrecen & Eindhoven Not Antwerp|publisher=Swimnews|date=16 February 2012|accessdate=24 March 2012}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.sportuszoda.hu/uk/index.html}} {{S-start}} {{Succession box | title = [[European Short Course Swimming Championships]]
Venue | years = '''[[2007 European Short Course Swimming Championships|2007]]''' | before = [[Mäkelänrinne Swimming Center]]
[[Helsinki]] | after = [[Kantrida Pool]]
[[Rijeka]] }} {{Succession box | title = [[European Aquatics Championships]]
Venue | years = '''[[2012 European Aquatics Championships|2012]]''' | with = [[Pieter van den Hoogenband Swimming Stadium]] | before = [[Alfréd Hajós National Swimming Stadium]]
[[Budapest]] | after = TBA
[[Berlin]] }} {{S-end}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2006]] [[Category:Swimming venues in Hungary]] [[Category:Sports venues in Debrecen]]

The '''Enduroman Arch to Arc Triathlon''' is an ultra-distance [[triathlon]]. The triathlon starts with an 87-mile run (140 km) from [[London]]'s [[Marble Arch]] to [[Dover]] on the [[Kent]] coast, then a cross-[[English Channel|Channel]] swim (shortest distance 21 miles/33,8 km) to the French coast, and finishes with a 180-mile (289,7 km) bike from [[Calais]] to the [[Arc de Triomphe]] in [[Paris]]. The clock starts at Marble Arch, London and stops at Arc de Triomphe, Paris. Only 28 athletes have ever completed the challenge. {{As of|2016|06}} the record for the course is 59 hours and 56 minutes, set Cyril Blanchard of France,{{cite news |author=Camille Dicrescenzo |url=http://france3-regions.francetvinfo.fr/hauts-de-france/le-beauvaisien-cyril-blanchard-bat-le-record-de-l-enduroman-2016-avec-59h56-1033387.html |title=Le Beauvaisien Cyril Blanchard bat le record de l'Enduroman 2016 |publisher=[[France 3]] |date=24 June 2016 |language=French }} beating the previous record of 61 hours, 27 minutes set in 2014 by [[Jon Van Wisse]] of Australia.{{cite news |author=Patrick Hatch |url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/swimming/australian-john-van-wisse-breaks-world-record-in-arch-to-arc-triathlon-from-london-to-paris-20140828-109tal.html |title=Australian John Van Wisse breaks world record in Arch to Arc triathlon from London to Paris |newspaper=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=29 August 2014 }} On August 19, 2011, Rachael Cadman became the first woman to complete the challenge, in 97 hours, 37 minutes.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14648738 |title=RAF officer Rachael Cadman completes Enduroman race |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=24 August 2011 }} Joanne Rodda finished in 78 hours, 39 minutes on 30 September 2014 to become the fastest female finisher.{{cite news |author=Natalie Glanvill |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/11555077.Psychiatrist_smashes_world_record_in_triathlon_challenge/ |title=Woodford Green resident is fastest female to complete 289-mile Arch to Arc triathlon |newspaper=[[Lancashire Telegraph]] |date=23 October 2014 }} In August 2015, 25-year-old Freddie Iron became the youngest man to complete the Arch to Arc, in a time of 77 hours, 17 minutes.{{cite web |url=https://www.sid.cam.ac.uk/life/news/797/freddie-irons-enduroman-arch-to-arc-charity-triathlon-triumph.html |title=Freddie Iron's Enduroman Arch to Arc charity triathlon triumph |publisher=[[Sidney Sussex College]], [[University of Cambridge]] |date=August 2015 }} On 21 September 2015, at 53 years old, Grantley Bridge became the oldest man to complete it, in 88 hours, 7 minutes. In 2018, the French woman Marine Leleu finishes the competition in 69 h 52, setting the new female record on the event. She will lose her title few weeks later due to Perrine Fages who finishes the competition in 67 h 21.{{Cite web|url=http://www.enduroman.com/records/4594246645|title=Records - Enduroman|website=www.enduroman.com|access-date=2018-08-31}} {{As of|2017|08}} the relay record is held by the six-person Team Manchester's Blood Brothers, with an overall time of 33 hours, 5 minutes in September 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.enduroman.com/#/arch-to-arc-records/4590689438 |title=Arch to Arc Records |publisher=Enduroman Ultra Events |accessdate=8 August 2017 }} In August 2017, Douglas Waymark got into difficulty about half-way through the cross-Channel swimming element of the event. After being airlifted to [[William Harvey Hospital]] in [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]], he later died.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-kent-40859655 |title=Douglas Waymark dies attempting to swim English Channel |date=8 August 2017 |publisher=BBC News }} ==Prize list==

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Estadio Manuel "Ciclón" Echeverría | nickname = El Ciclón | image = [[Image:Estadio Manuel "Ciclón" Echeverría.jpg|300px|Ciclón]] | | fullname = | location = [[Navojoa]], [[Sonora]], [[México]] | coordinates = {{coord|27|03|46|N|109|27|04.68|W|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = October 7th, 1970 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Sonora|Sonora State Government]] | operator = [[Mayos de Navojoa|Promociones Deportivas del Mayo SA de CV]] | surface = Bermuda Grass | construction_cost = | architect = Arq. Carlos Perez Pliego Soto | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = Estadio Municipal de Navojoa | tenants = [[Mayos de Navojoa]] ([[Mexican Pacific League|LMP]]) (1970-present) | seating_capacity = 11,500 | dimensions = LF: 328 ft, CF: 400 ft, RF: 328 ft }} '''Estadio Manuel "Ciclón" Echeverría''' is a [[stadium]] in [[Navojoa]], [[Sonora]], named after one local baseball player, [[Manuel Echeverría]], nicknamed "Ciclón". He is a member of the [[Salón de la Fama del Beisbol Profesional de México|Mexican Baseball Hall of Fame]]. It is used for [[baseball]], and is the home field of the [[Mayos de Navojoa]] [[Mexican Pacific League]] baseball team. It opened on October 7, 1970 {{cite web|author=Club de Beisbol Mayos de Navojoa|title=Estadio|year=|accessdate=|url=http://mayosbeisbol.com/estadio.html}} and holds 11,500 people, all seated. It is located within the Unidad Deportiva [[Faustino Félix Serna]]. ;Dimensions :Left Field - 328 ft (100 m)

The '''Hutt Valley Spartans''' are a [[minor league]] [[American football]] team. They are a member of American Football Wellington (AFW). In 2006, the Spartans won the Capital Bowl, American Football Wellington’s ultimate prize in their second full year in the competition. IN 2007 & 2008 they end up with two third-place finishes. In 2010-2011 they won the Capital Bowl by defeating the Wellington Wolves by 34-8 They play home games at [[Spartan Park]] (grass field, maximum capacity of 1,000) in [[Avalon, New Zealand|Avalon]], [[New Zealand]]. In recent past they have had 2 undefeated regular seasons in a row the 2016-17 they narrowly lost in the capital bowl and in the 2017-18 season they were able to lift the cup again.
