==1990s== [[#1990|1990]] – [[#1991|1991]] – [[#1992|1992]] – [[#1993|1993]] – [[#1994|1994]] – [[#1995|1995]] – [[#1996|1996]] – [[#1997|1997]] – [[#1998|1998]] – [[#1999|1999]]
===1990=== *ASC Linguère won their third cup title *[[ASC Port Autonome|UCST Port Autonome]] won their first championship title
===1991=== *ASC Diaraf won their ninth cup title *ASC Port Autonome won their second championship title<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesk/sene91.html Senegal 1991 at RSSSF]</ref> *ASC Diaraf won their second National Assembly (super cup) title
===1992=== *ASC Jeanne d'Arc participated in the 1992 WAFU Club Championship *US Gorée won their third cup title *[[ASEC Ndiambour]] won their first championship title<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesk/sene92.html Senegal 1992], RSSSF</ref>
===1993=== *ASC Diaraf won their tenth cup title<ref name="RSSSF">[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesc/sene93.html Senegal 1992/93], RSSSF</ref> *[[AS Douanes (Senegal)|AS Douanes]] won their first championship title<ref name="RSSSF"/> *Dial Diop disqualified as they forfeited two matches, all matches that Dial Diop took part were annulled
===1994=== *ASC Diaraf won their eleventh cup title *ASEC Ndiamnbour won their second championship title
===1995=== *ASC Diaraf won their twelfth cup title *ASC Diaraf won their ninth championship title<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesk/sene95.html 1995 Senegalese Division 1 - rsssf.com]</ref>
===1996=== *ASEC Ndiambour took part in the 1996 WAFU Club Championship *US Gorée won their fourth and last cup title *Diourbel as SONACOS (now ASC SUNEOR) won their fourth championship title and the only under the name
===1997=== *[[ASC Saloum]] football club founded after the merger of AS Kaolack and Mbossé-Kaolack *AS Douanes won their second cup title *AS Douanes won their second championship title
===1998=== *ASC Jeanne d'Arc won their and last ninth cup title *ASEC Ndiambour won their third and last championship title *ASEC Ndiambour won their first National Assembly (super cup) title
===1999=== *[[ASC Yeggo]] won their only cup title *ASC Jeanne d'Arc won their seventh championship title<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene99.html 1999 Senegalese Division 1], RSSSF</ref> *The 1999 National Assembly edition was cancelled
==2000s== [[#2000|2000]] – [[#2001|2001]] – [[#2002|2002]] – [[#2003|2003]] – [[#2004|2004]] – [[#2005|2005]] – [[#2006|2006]] – [[#2007|2007]] – [[#2008|2008]] – [[#2009|2009]]
===2000=== *[[ASC Port Autonome]] won their only cup title *ASC Diaraf won their tenth championship title<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene00.html 2000 Senegalese Division 1], RSSSF</ref> *ASC Port Autonome won their only National Assembly (super cup) title *[[Diambars FC]] of Saly founded
===2001=== *ASC Jeanne d'Arc won their tenth cup title *ASC Jeanne d'Arc won their eighth championship title<ref name="rsssf.com">[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene01.html 2001 Senegalese Division 1], RSSSF</ref> *ASC Jeanne d'Arc won their third and last National Assembly (super cup) title
===2002=== *AS Douanes won their third cup title *ASC Jeanne d'Arc won their ninth championship title and their second consecutive<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene02.html 2002 Senegalese Division 1], RSSSF</ref> *ASEC Ndiambour won their second National Assembly (super cup) title
===2003=== *AS Douanes won their fourth cup title and their second consecutive *ASC Jeanne d'Arc won their tenth championship title and their third consecutive<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene03.html 2003 Senegalese Division 1], RSSSF</ref> *ASC Diaraf won their third National Assembly (super cup) title
===2004=== *ASC Diaraf won their eleventh championship title<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene04.html 2004 Senegalese Division 1], RSSSF</ref> *AS Douanes won their fifth cup title and their third consecutive *ASEC Ndiambour won their fourth and last National Assembly (super cup) title
===2005=== *AS Douanes won their sixth and last cup title and their fourth consecutive *ASC Port Autonome won their third and last championship title.<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene05.html 2005 Senegalese Division 1], RSSSF</ref> *SONACOS (now ASC SUNEOR) Djourbel won their only National Assembly (super cup) title
===2006=== *AS Douanes won their third championship title<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene06.html 2005/06 Senegalese Premier Division season at RSSSF]</ref> *US Ouakam won their third and last cup title *ASC Diaraf won their fourth and last National Assembly (super cup) title
===2007=== *ASC Linguère won their fourth and final cup title *AS Douanes won their fourth consecutive championship title and their second consecutive<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene07.html 2006/07 Senegalese Premier Division season at RSSSF]</ref>
===2008=== *ASC Diaraf won their thirteenth cup title *AS Douanes won their fifth championship title and their third consecutive<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene08.html 2008 Senegalese Premier Division season at RSSSF]</ref> *[[ASC Yakaar]] won their only National Assembly (super cup) title *Division 1 becomes a professional competition
===2009=== *ASC Diaraf won their fourteenth cup title and their second consecutive *AS Douanes won their first [[Senegalese League Cup]] *ASC Linguère won their first and only championship title after the merger<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene09.html 2009 Senegalese Premier League season at RSSSF]</ref> *Division 1 and 2 became Ligue 1 and 2, the lower three became Nationale 1 and 2
==2010s== [[#2010|2010]] – [[#2011|2011]] – [[#2012|2012]] – [[#2013|2013]] – [[#2014|2014]] – [[#2015|2015]] – [[#2016|2016]] – [[#2017|2017]]
===2010=== *ASC Diaraf won their twelfth and last championship title<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene2010.html 2010 Senegalese Premier League season at RSSSF]</ref> *Casa Sport won their first [[Senegalese League Cup|league cup]] *[[Toure Kunda Footpro]] (now Mbour Petite-Côté) won their only cup title *[[Stade de Mbour]] won their only National Assembly (super cup) title
===2011=== *AS Pikine won their only league cup title *US Ouakam won their only championship title<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene2011.html 2011 Senegalese Premier League season at RSSSF]</ref> *Casa Sport won their second and last cup title *Diambars FC won their first consecutive National Assembly (super cup) title
===2012=== *[[ASC HLM]] won their only cup title *ASC Niarry-Tally won their only league cup title *Casa Sports won their only championship title<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene2012.html 2012 Senegalese Premier League season at RSSSF]</ref> *Diambars FC won their second consecutive National Assembly (super cup) title
===2013=== *ASC Diaraf won their fifteenth and last cup title *Casa Sport won their second and last league cup title *[[Diambars FC]] of Saly won their only championship title<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene2013.html 2013 Senegalese Premier League season at RSSSF]</ref> *Diambars FC won their third consecutive and last National Assembly (super cup) title
===2014=== *AS Pikine from suburban Dakar won their only cup title *[[AS Pikine]] from suburban Dakar won their only championship title<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene2014.html 2014 Senegalese Premier League season at RSSSF]</ref> *[[Olympique de Ngor]] won their only National Assembly (super cup) title *[[Guédiawaye FC]] won their only league cup title
===2015=== *AS Douanes won their second and last league cup title *[[Génération Foot]] won their only cup title *AS Douanes won their sixth and last championship title<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sene2015.html 2015 Senegalese Premier League season at RSSSF]</ref> *As a second placed cup winner, [[Olympique de Ngor]] competed in the [[2015 CAF Confederation Cup]] *The National Assembly Cup becomes the Super Cup *AS Douanes won their only super cup title
===2016=== *Diambars FC won their only league cup title *[[ASC Niarry Tally|ASC Niarry-Tally]] won their only cup title *US Gorée won their fourth and last championship title<ref>{{cite web|title=Le Soleil - Gorée, championne du Sénégal: Ndiambour et Douane évitent la relégation|url=http://www.lesoleil.sn/2016-03-22-23-49-47/item/51208-goree-championne-du-senegal-ndiambour-et-douane-evitent-la-relegation.html|accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> *US Gorée won their only super cup title *US Gorée won their only Champion's Trophy
===2017=== *[[Génération Foot]] won their only championship title, Ligue 1 *[[Mbour Petite-Côte FC|Mbour Petite-Côte]] won their only national cup title *[[Stade de Mbour]] won their League Cup title *[[US Ouakam]] demoted, the club was out of competition as the team took the case to the international football court in Geneva, Switzerland where they won their right to remain in Ligue 1

revision.text:
{{Infobox football biography
|name = Vashami Allen |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1997|4|9}} |birth_place = [[All Saints, Antigua and Barbuda]] |height = 1.83m |position = [[Defender (association football)|Defender]] |currentclub = |years1 = –2015 |clubs1 = [[All Saints United F.C.]] |years2 = 2015–2016 |clubs2 = [[Fort Road FC]] |years3 = 2016–2017 |clubs3 = [[All Saints United F.C.]] |years4 = 2017 |clubs4 = [[Central FC]] |nationalyears1 = |nationalteam1 = [[Antigua and Barbuda national under-20 football team|Antigua and Barbuda U20]] |nationalyears2 = 2015–2016 |nationalteam2 = [[Antigua and Barbuda national football team|Antigua and Barbuda]] |nationalcaps2 = 2 |nationalgoals2 = 0 }}
'''Vashami Allen''' (born 9 May 1997 in [[All Saints, Antigua and Barbuda]]) is an [[Antigua and Barbuda|Antiguan]] footballer who last operated as defender for [[Central FC]] in the [[TT Pro League]]. His football ambition is to play in Europe.<ref name="concacaf"/>
==Early life==
First getting involved in football at his primary school, the Antiguan was identified as a possible talent by coaches there, starting his football career.<ref name="concacaf"/> Growing up, Allen saw Antiguan footballer [[Dave Carr (footballer, born 1982)|Dave Carr]] play frequently for the national team.<ref name="concacaf"/>
==Career==
===Central FC===
One of 12 players sent to Central FC on three-week contracts to help the club in its audacious attempt to win three CFU Club Championships in succession,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wired868.com/2017/05/11/foreign-legion-central-fc-fly-in-12-players-on-three-week-contracts-for-caribbean-cup/|title=Foreign legion: Central FC fly in 12 players on three-week contracts for Caribbean Cup – Wired868|website=wired868.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://antiguaobserver.com/antiguan-defender-signed-by-tt-pro-club/|title=Antiguan Defender Signed By T&T Pro Club|date=28 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref> Allen refused to renew his contract with the club after claiming to have been living in poor conditions and not getting a monthly wage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportcaraibe.com/breaking-news/antigua-players-refused-to-renew-tt-pro-league-contracts/|title=Antigua players refused to renew TT Pro League contracts – SPORT Caraibe|website=www.sportcaraibe.com}}</ref>
===International===
Named on the [[Antigua and Barbuda national under-20 football team|Antigua and Barbuda Under-20]] roster in 2016, the defender helped the team finish second behind [[Haiti national under-20 football team|Haiti]] to qualify for the [[2017 CONCACAF U-20 Championship]],<ref name="concacaf">{{cite web|url=http://www.concacaf.com/article/concacaf-qa-vashami-allen-all-saints-united-and-antigua-barbuda|title=CONCACAF Q&A: Vashami Allen (All Saints United and Antigua & Barbuda)|website=CONCACAF}}</ref> getting a spot in the [[2017 CONCACAF U-20 Championship qualifying|Caribbean qualifying]] Best Eleven.<ref name="concacaf"/> Making his second senior national team cap against [[Estonia national football team|Estonia]], Allen nervousness ahead of the game was alleviated by encouragement from the senior players and put up a solid performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.concacaf.com/article/allen-relishes-dual-antigua-barbuda-role|title=Allen relishes dual Antigua & Barbuda role|website=CONCACAF}}</ref>
==References==
{{reflist}}
[[Category:Expatriate footballers in Trinidad and Tobago]] [[Category:Antigua and Barbuda expatriate footballers]] [[Category:Antigua and Barbuda footballers]] [[Category:Antigua and Barbuda international footballers]] [[Category:Association football defenders]] [[Category:1997 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Central F.C. players]] [[Category:TT Pro League players]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = VIDA Arena | image = [[File:VIDAarena.jpg|250px|The interior of Vida Arena, nearly two weeks before the premier game.]] | location = [[Växjö]], [[Sweden]] | coordinates = {{Coord|56|52|47|N|14|46|25|E|type:landmark_scale:1000|display=it}} | broke_ground = September 2010 | opened = 17 September 2011 | owner = [[Växjö Lakers]] | tenants = [[Växjö Lakers]] ([[Swedish Hockey League|SHL]]) (2011–present) | seating_capacity = [[Ice hockey]]: 5,700 }}
'''Vida Arena''' (branded as '''VIDA Arena''') is a [[multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose]] indoor [[arena]] located in [[Växjö]], [[Sweden]]. The arena opened in September 2011 and is best known as the home arena for the [[ice hockey]] team [[Växjö Lakers]]. It seats 5,700 spectators.<ref name="5700 spectators" />
==Construction== The construction of Vida Arena began in September 2010 and was finished in summer 2011, in time for the [[Växjö Lakers]]' debut season in the [[Swedish Hockey League|Elitserien]] (now named the SHL), the top-tier ice hockey league in Sweden. Although mainly intended to be used for [[ice hockey]], Vida Arena is also used for other events such as [[concert]]s and [[news conference]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smp.se/sport/vida-arena---i-14-ar%282119511%29.gm |title=Vida arena - i 14 år |publisher=''Smålandsposten'' |author=Daniel Rydström |language=Swedish |date=2010-09-25 |accessdate=2011-09-01}}</ref> The arena is named after the [[Vida AB|Vida Group]], the company that acquired the [[naming rights]] for Vida Arena in September 2010, for the upcoming 14 seasons (expiring after the 2023–24 season).<ref name="VIDA information">{{cite web |url=http://www.vida.se/vida-arena-namnet-pa-vaxjo-lakers-nya-hockeyarena-.aspx |title=VIDA Arena - namnet på Växjö Lakers nya hockeyarena |publisher=[[Vida AB|Vida Group]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2011-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002163137/http://www.vida.se/vida-arena-namnet-pa-vaxjo-lakers-nya-hockeyarena-.aspx |archivedate=2011-10-02 |df= }}</ref>
==Spectator capacity== As of the [[2013–14 SHL season|2013–14 season]], Vida Arena is the [[Swedish Hockey League|SHL]]'s newest arena and has a [[seating capacity|spectator capacity]] of 5,700, making it the SHL's capacity-wise next-to-smallest arena, only surpassing Örebro's [[Behrn Arena (ice hockey)|Behrn Arena]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vaxjolakers.se/vida-arena/fakta-om-vida-arena |title=Fakta om VIDA Arena |publisher=[[Växjö Lakers Hockey|Växjö Lakers]] |author= |language=Swedish |date= |accessdate=2012-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120416013028/http://www.vaxjolakers.se/vida-arena/fakta-om-vida-arena |archivedate=2012-04-16 |df= }}</ref>
For the entire [[2011–12 Elitserien season|2011–12 season]], the arena had a capacity of 5,329 spectators. Plans were announced to extend the capacity to at least 6,000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smp.se/sport/snart-plats-for-6-000-askadare%282796358%29.gm |title=Snart plats för 6 000 åskådare |publisher=''Smålandsposten'' |author=Daniel Enestubbe |language=Swedish |date=2011-05-27 |accessdate=2011-09-01}}</ref><ref name="5800 spectators" /> Prior to the beginning of the [[2012–13 Elitserien season|2012–13 season]], the capacity was increased to 5,800 spectators.<ref name="5800 spectators">{{cite web |url=http://www.vaxjolakers.se/artikel/28014/ |title=Vida Arena växer |publisher=[[Växjö Lakers]] |last=Gustavsson |first=Jonas |language=Swedish |date=2012-09-14 |accessdate=2013-01-30}}</ref> In October 2012, however, the capacity was slightly reduced to 5,700 due to concerns from spectators. Level 4 was mainly affected.<ref name="5700 spectators">{{cite web |url=http://www.vaxjolakers.se/artikel/28967/ |title=Ny publikkapacitet: 5700 |publisher=[[Växjö Lakers]] |last=Gustavsson |first=Jonas |language=Swedish |date=2012-10-03 |accessdate=2013-01-30}}</ref>
==Inauguration== The arena was officially inaugurated on 17 September 2011, in an ice hockey game between Växjö Lakers and [[Linköpings HC]]. The arena tickets for the game were outsold within just one hour, with the Lakers' [[marketing management|marketing manager]] speculating that they could've sold out two arenas.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/sportbladet/hockey/sverige/elitserien/vaxjo/article13582651.ab |title=Hade kunnat sälja ut två arenor |publisher=''[[Aftonbladet]]'' |author=Hampus Hagman |language=Swedish |date=2011-09-06 |accessdate=2011-09-10}}</ref> Former Växjö Lakers crowd favorite [[Shjon Podein]] watched the game live in the arena. Linköping won the game 4–2 in front of 5,502 spectators.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vaxjolakers.se/artikel/3852/ |title=Förlust i hemmapremiären |publisher=[[Växjö Lakers Hockey|Växjö Lakers]] |author=Jonas Gustavsson |language=Swedish |date=2011-09-17 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vaxjolakers.se/artikel/3826/ |title=Invigningsöverraskningen: Podein på plats i VIDA Arena |publisher=[[Växjö Lakers Hockey|Växjö Lakers]] |author=Jonas Gustavsson |language=Swedish |date=2011-09-16 |accessdate=2011-09-16}}</ref> However, the Lakers' premier game on 13 September, on away ice against [[Frölunda HC]], was shown on the Vida Arena's [[Jumbotron]] in front of 2,400 spectators, with free entrance, as a preview of the Vida Arena experience and a test of the arena's technical features. Frölunda won the game 2–0.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vaxjolakers.se/website1/sv/nyhetsmall/nyhetsmall.php?item=cms_12-s1/960&group=cms_12_grp-s1/3 |title=Frölunda-Växjö Lakers live i VIDA Arena |publisher=[[Växjö Lakers Hockey|Växjö Lakers]] |language=Swedish |date=2011-09-09 |accessdate=2011-09-10 }}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smp.se/sport/frolundavaxjo-live-i-vida-arena%282934904%29.gm |title=Frölunda–Växjö live i Vida Arena |publisher=''Smålandsposten'' |author=Daniel Enestubbe |language=Swedish |date=2011-09-09 |accessdate=2011-09-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vaxjolakers.se/artikel/2206/ |title=2 400 besökte VIDA Arena |author=Jonas Gustavsson |publisher=[[Växjö Lakers Hockey|Växjö Lakers]] |language=Swedish |date=2011-09-13 |accessdate=2011-09-16}}</ref>
==Arenastaden== Vida Arena is part of the [[sports complex]] "Arenastaden" (''Arena town''), which also includes a [[Myresjöhus Arena|new football stadium]], a [[floorball]] arena, and an arena for [[athletics (sport)|athletics]].<ref name="Arenastaden">{{cite web|url=http://www.vaxjo.se/default.aspx?id=6617 |title=Arenastaden in Växjö |publisher=Växjö |language=Swedish |accessdate=2011-04-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110129215330/http://www.vaxjo.se/default.aspx?id=6617 |archivedate=2011-01-29 |df= }}</ref> Vida Arena is connected with [[Växjö Ishall]], an old arena inaugurated in 1970 which, since a [[renovation]] which took place in 2006, has a capacity of 4,000 spectators.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://vaxjo.se/-/Arenastaden-i-Vaxjo---Startsida/Arenor/Befintliga-arenor/Vaxjo-Ishall/ |title=Växjö Ishall |publisher=''vaxjo.se'' |author= |language=Swedish |date= |accessdate=2011-10-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425080234/http://vaxjo.se/-/Arenastaden-i-Vaxjo---Startsida/Arenor/Befintliga-arenor/Vaxjo-Ishall/ |archive-date=2012-04-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Other events== Vida Arena hosted the first semifinal of [[Melodifestivalen 2012]] on 4 February 2012. This was the third time that [[Växjö]] hosted a [[Melodifestivalen]] stage, after [[Melodifestivalen 2002|2002]] and [[Melodifestivalen 2005|2005]] (both times in [[Tipshallen]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=148439&a=2518070 |title=Städerna som får besök av Melodifestivalen 2012 |publisher=''[[Sveriges Television]]'' |language=Swedish |date=2011-09-01 |accessdate=2011-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111104084152/http://svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=148439&a=2518070 |archivedate=2011-11-04 |df= }}</ref>
==Sans Cash== Vida Arena is the first cashless arena in Sweden.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vaxjolakers.se/website1/sv/nyhetsmall/nyhetsmall.php?item=cms_12-s1/896&group=cms_12_grp-s1/3 |title=Sveriges första kontantfria arena |publisher=[[Växjö Lakers Hockey]] |language=Swedish |date=2011-08-12 |accessdate=2011-08-13 }}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery caption="Images of Vida Arena" widths="225px" heights="150px" perrow="3"> Vida Arena skymning 6497.jpg | Vida Arena's west part of the front exterior. Vida Arena Växjö 20101004-forsta laktaren.jpg | The construction of Vida Arena started in September 2010. </gallery>
==Panorama image== {{wide image|Vida Arena pano 2011-09-08.jpg|1200px|alt=Panorama of Vida Arena's ice hockey rink from the restaurant.}}
== References == {{reflist|33em}}
== External links == *[https://archive.is/20130113192439/http://vidaarena.se/ Official website for Vida Arena]

revision.text:
A '''welding helmet''' is a type of [[Personal protective equipment|headgear]] used when performing certain types of [[welding]] to protect the eyes, face and neck from flash burn, [[ultraviolet light]], [[Spark (fire)|sparks]], [[infrared light]], and heat.
Welding helmets are most commonly used with [[arc welding]] processes such as [[shielded metal arc welding]], [[gas tungsten arc welding]], and [[gas metal arc welding]]. They are necessary to prevent [[arc eye]], a painful condition where the [[cornea]] is inflamed. Welding helmets can also prevent [[retina]] burns, which can lead to a loss of vision. Both conditions are caused by unprotected exposure to the highly concentrated ultraviolet and infrared rays emitted by the welding arc.<ref>[http://www.elvex.com/facts11.htm Elvex Safety Products ''How Light Affects the Eye'']</ref> Ultraviolet emissions from the welding arc can also damage uncovered skin, causing a [[sunburn]]-like condition in a relatively short period of welding. In addition to the radiation, gasses or splashes can also be a hazard to the skin and the eyes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.testbericht-testsieger.de/kaufberatung-automatik-schweissmasken-schweisshelme/|title=Testbericht zur Automatik-Schweißmaske Speedglas 100 von 3M|date=2017-01-12|newspaper=Testberichte für Testsieger|language=de-DE|access-date=2017-01-29}}</ref>
The modern welding helmet used today was first introduced in 1937 by Willson Products.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=79oDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA217&dq=Popular+Science+1933+plane+%22Popular+Mechanics%22&hl=en&ei=RasMTuyGFYifsQLC3sGzCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CC0Q6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q&f=true "One Piece Helmet Cut To Protect The Welder] ''Popular Mechanics'', August 1937 -- bottom-left of page 217</ref>
Most welding helmets include a window covered with a filter called a lens shade, through which the welder can see to work. In most helmets, the window may be made of tinted glass, tinted plastic, or a variable-density filter made from a pair of [[polarizer|polarized]] lenses.
==Safety== All welding helmets are susceptible to damages such as cracks that can compromise the protection from ultraviolet and infrared rays. In addition to protecting the eyes, the helmet protects the face from hot metal sparks generated by the arc and from UV damage. When overhead welding, a leather skull cap and shoulder cover are used to prevent head and shoulder burns.<ref>{{Citation | last = Miller | first = Mark R. | title = Welding Licensing Exam Study Guide | page = 5 | publisher = McGraw-Hill Professional | year = 2007 | isbn = 978-0-07-149376-5 | postscript =.}}</ref>
==Auto-darkening filters== [[Image:Speedglas.jpg|thumb|Speedglas welding helmet.]] In 1981, Swedish manufacturer Hornell International introduced an LCD electronic shutter that darkens automatically when sensors detect the bright welding arc,<ref name=speedglas>[http://www.3m.com/product/information/Speedglas-Welding.html 3M Speedglas Auto-Darkening Welding Helmet ]</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.testbericht-testsieger.de/technische-entwicklung-automatischer-schweisserschutzfilter/|title=Technische Entwicklung automatischer Schweißerschutzfilter|date=2017-01-19|newspaper=Testberichte für Testsieger|language=de-DE|access-date=2017-01-29}}</ref> the Speedglas Auto-Darkening Filter.
With such electronic auto-darkening helmets, the welder no longer has to get ready to weld and then nod their head to lower the helmet over their face. The advantage is that the welder does not need to adjust the position of welding helmet manually which not only saves time but also reduces the risk of exposure to the harmful light generated by the welding process.
In January 2004, 3M acquired all assets of Hornell, including the Adflo and Speedglas auto darkening helmets brand name and patents. Speedglas helmets are now sold by 3M.<ref>[http://news.3m.com/press-release/company/3m-acquire-hornell-international-expands-safety-products-line 3m.com]</ref>
==ANSI standards== In the United States, the industry standard for welding helmets is ANSI Z87.1+ which specifies performance of a wide variety of eye protection devices. The standard requires that auto-darkening helmets provide full protection against both UV and IR even when they are not in the darkened state.<ref name=":0" /> The standard is voluntary, so buyers should confirm that the helmet is ANSI Z87.1 compliant (indicated by appropriate labeling).
==See also== * [[Welding goggles]], used in [[Oxy-fuel welding and cutting|torch welding]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox Venue | name = Zepyur Football Training Camp | image = Zepyur camp, Pyunik village 21.06.2012.jpg | image_caption = | nickname = | location = [[Pyunik (village)|Pyunik]]
[[Kotayk Province]], [[Armenia]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|36|24|N|44|36|00|E|region:ES-M_type:landmark_source:dewiki|display=inline,title}} | type = [[Mountain resort]] & [[Training ground (association football)|Football training camp]] | opened = 2011 | owner = Zepyur Summer Complex | construction_cost= | former_names = | website = [https://web.archive.org/web/20150413161837/http://www.zepyur.am/about/ Zepyur Camp] }} '''Zepyur Football Training Camp''' ({{lang-hy|Զեփյուռ Ամառային Ճամբար}}), is a [[association football|football]] [[training ground|training camp]] in the [[Pyunik (village)|Pyunik]] village of [[Kotayk Province]], on the left bank of Marmarik River. The training camp is provided by a hotel, a restaurant as well as other entertainment facilities. ==Overview== The training camp was opened in 2011 on the grounds of the former Kilikia Camp, following a large scale redevelopment process during 2010.[https://web.archive.org/web/20150413161837/http://www.zepyur.am/about/ Zepyur Camp] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150413161837/http://www.zepyur.am/about/ |date=13 April 2015 }} Currently, the camp is home to the following facilities: * 2 regular-sized football training natural grass pitches. * 1 mini football artificial turf pitch. * 1 outdoor basketball court. * 1 outdoor swimming pool. * Hotel with a restaurant and sanatorium. * Service centre with billiards room, table tennis, gymnasium and open-air cinema. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.wvarmenia.am/am/photo-gallery/show/30 Images of the Zepyur Camp] {{Football venues in Armenia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zepyur Football Training Camp}} [[Category:Association football training grounds in Armenia]] [[Category:2011 establishments in Armenia]] [[Category:Hotels in Armenia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2011]]
